trans-unit.source: Create a PHP web app in Azure App Service using Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Create a PHP web app in Azure App Service using Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create a PHP web app in Azure App Service and use the Azure Tables storage service in the back-end.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create a PHP web app in Azure App Service and use the Azure Tables storage service in the back-end.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to create a PHP web app in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> and use the Azure Tables storage service in the back-end.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to create a PHP web app in <linkText>Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> and use the Azure Tables storage service in the back-end.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes you have <linkText>PHP[install-php]</linkText><title></title> and a web server installed on your computer.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes you have <linkText>PHP[install-php]</linkText><title></title> and a web server installed on your computer.

trans-unit.source: The instructions in this tutorial can be followed on any operating system, including Windows, Mac, and Linux.
trans-unit.target: The instructions in this tutorial can be followed on any operating system, including Windows, Mac, and Linux.

trans-unit.source: Upon completing this guide, you will have a PHP web app running in Azure and accessing the Table storage service.
trans-unit.target: Upon completing this guide, you will have a PHP web app running in Azure and accessing the Table storage service.

trans-unit.source: You will learn:
trans-unit.target: You will learn:

trans-unit.source: How to install the Azure client libraries and include them into your application.
trans-unit.target: How to install the Azure client libraries and include them into your application.

trans-unit.source: How to use the client libraries for creating tables, and for creating, querying and deleting table entities.
trans-unit.target: How to use the client libraries for creating tables, and for creating, querying and deleting table entities.

trans-unit.source: How to create an Azure Storage Account and set up your application to use it.
trans-unit.target: How to create an Azure Storage Account and set up your application to use it.

trans-unit.source: How to create an Azure web app and deploy to it using Git
trans-unit.target: How to create an Azure web app and deploy to it using Git

trans-unit.source: You will build a simple Tasklist web application in PHP.
trans-unit.target: You will build a simple Tasklist web application in PHP.

trans-unit.source: A screenshot of the completed application is below:
trans-unit.target: A screenshot of the completed application is below:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure PHP web app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure PHP web app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: To install the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To install the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Install Git[install-git]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Install Git[install-git]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: On Windows, you will also need to add the Git executable to your PATH environment variable.
trans-unit.target: On Windows, you will also need to add the Git executable to your PATH environment variable.

trans-unit.source: Create a file named composer.json in the root of your project and add the following code to it:
trans-unit.target: Create a file named composer.json in the root of your project and add the following code to it:

trans-unit.source: Download **<linkText>composer.phar[composer-phar]</linkText><title></title>** in your project root.
trans-unit.target: Download **<linkText>composer.phar[composer-phar]</linkText><title></title>** in your project root.

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt and execute this in your project root
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt and execute this in your project root

trans-unit.source: There are four basic steps that have to be performed before you can make a call to an Azure API wen using the libraries.
trans-unit.target: There are four basic steps that have to be performed before you can make a call to an Azure API wen using the libraries.

trans-unit.source: You will create an initialization script that will perform these steps.
trans-unit.target: You will create an initialization script that will perform these steps.

trans-unit.source: Create a file called init.php.
trans-unit.target: Create a file called init.php.

trans-unit.source: First, include the autoloader script:
trans-unit.target: First, include the autoloader script:

trans-unit.source: Include the namespaces you are going to use.
trans-unit.target: Include the namespaces you are going to use.

trans-unit.source: To create any Azure service client you need to use the ServicesBuilder class:
trans-unit.target: To create any Azure service client you need to use the ServicesBuilder class:

trans-unit.source: To catch exceptions produced by any API call you need the ServiceException class:
trans-unit.target: To catch exceptions produced by any API call you need the ServiceException class:

trans-unit.source: To instantiate the service client you will also need a valid connection string.
trans-unit.target: To instantiate the service client you will also need a valid connection string.

trans-unit.source: The format for the table service connection strings is:
trans-unit.target: The format for the table service connection strings is:

trans-unit.source: For accessing a live service:
trans-unit.target: For accessing a live service:

trans-unit.source: For accessing the emulator storage:
trans-unit.target: For accessing the emulator storage:

trans-unit.source: Use the ServicesBuilder::createTableService factory method to instantiate a wrapper around Table service calls.
trans-unit.target: Use the ServicesBuilder::createTableService factory method to instantiate a wrapper around Table service calls.

trans-unit.source: $tableRestProxy contains a method for every REST call available on Azure Tables.
trans-unit.target: $tableRestProxy contains a method for every REST call available on Azure Tables.

trans-unit.source: Before you can store data you first have to create a container for it, the Table.
trans-unit.target: Before you can store data you first have to create a container for it, the Table.

trans-unit.source: Create a file named createtable.php.
trans-unit.target: Create a file named createtable.php.

trans-unit.source: First, include the initialization script you just created.
trans-unit.target: First, include the initialization script you just created.

trans-unit.source: You will be including this script in every file accessing Azure:
trans-unit.target: You will be including this script in every file accessing Azure:

trans-unit.source: Then, make a call to createTable passing in the name of the table.
trans-unit.target: Then, make a call to createTable passing in the name of the table.

trans-unit.source: Similarly to other NoSQL table stores, no schema is required for Azure Tables.
trans-unit.target: Similarly to other NoSQL table stores, no schema is required for Azure Tables.

trans-unit.source: Error codes and message scan be found here: <linkText>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/dd179438.aspx[msdn-errors]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Error codes and message scan be found here: <linkText>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windowsazure/dd179438.aspx[msdn-errors]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: The home page of the Tasklist application should list all existing tasks and allow the insertion of new ones.
trans-unit.target: The home page of the Tasklist application should list all existing tasks and allow the insertion of new ones.

trans-unit.source: Create a file named index.php and insert the following HTML and PHP code which will form the header of the page:
trans-unit.target: Create a file named index.php and insert the following HTML and PHP code which will form the header of the page:

trans-unit.source: To query Azure Tables for all entities stored in the tasks table you call the queryEntities method passing only the name of the table.
trans-unit.target: To query Azure Tables for all entities stored in the tasks table you call the queryEntities method passing only the name of the table.

trans-unit.source: In the Updating an Entity section below you will also see how to pass a filter querying for a specific entity.
trans-unit.target: In the Updating an Entity section below you will also see how to pass a filter querying for a specific entity.

trans-unit.source: To iterate on the entities in the result set:
trans-unit.target: To iterate on the entities in the result set:

trans-unit.source: Once you get an Entity, the model for reading data is Entity->getPropertyValue('[name]'):
trans-unit.target: Once you get an Entity, the model for reading data is Entity->getPropertyValue('[name]'):

trans-unit.source: Last, you must insert the form that feeds data into the task insertion script and complete the HTML:
trans-unit.target: Last, you must insert the form that feeds data into the task insertion script and complete the HTML:

trans-unit.source: Your application can now read all items stored in the table.
trans-unit.target: Your application can now read all items stored in the table.

trans-unit.source: Since there won't be any at fist, let's add a function that writes data into the database.
trans-unit.target: Since there won't be any at fist, let's add a function that writes data into the database.

trans-unit.source: Create a file named additem.php.
trans-unit.target: Create a file named additem.php.

trans-unit.source: Add the following to the file:
trans-unit.target: Add the following to the file:

trans-unit.source: The first step of inserting an entity is instantiating an Entity object and setting the properties on it:
trans-unit.target: The first step of inserting an entity is instantiating an Entity object and setting the properties on it:

trans-unit.source: Then you can pass the $entity you just created to the insertEntity method:
trans-unit.target: Then you can pass the $entity you just created to the insertEntity method:

trans-unit.source: Last, to make the page return to the home page after inserting the entity:
trans-unit.target: Last, to make the page return to the home page after inserting the entity:

trans-unit.source: The task list app has the ability to mark an item as complete as well as to unmark it.
trans-unit.target: The task list app has the ability to mark an item as complete as well as to unmark it.

trans-unit.source: The home page passes in the RowKey and PartitionKey of an entity and the target state (marked==1, unmarked==0).
trans-unit.target: The home page passes in the RowKey and PartitionKey of an entity and the target state (marked==1, unmarked==0).

trans-unit.source: Create a file called markitem.php and add the initialization part:
trans-unit.target: Create a file called markitem.php and add the initialization part:

trans-unit.source: The first step to updating an entity is fetching it from the Table:
trans-unit.target: The first step to updating an entity is fetching it from the Table:

trans-unit.source: As you can see the passed in query filter is of the form Key eq 'Value'.
trans-unit.target: As you can see the passed in query filter is of the form Key eq 'Value'.

trans-unit.source: A full description of the query syntax is available <linkText>here[msdn-table-query-syntax]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: A full description of the query syntax is available <linkText>here[msdn-table-query-syntax]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Then you can change any properties:
trans-unit.target: Then you can change any properties:

trans-unit.source: And the updateEntity method performs the update:
trans-unit.target: And the updateEntity method performs the update:

trans-unit.source: To make the page return to the home page after inserting the entity:
trans-unit.target: To make the page return to the home page after inserting the entity:

trans-unit.source: Deleting an item is accomplished with a single call to deleteItem.
trans-unit.target: Deleting an item is accomplished with a single call to deleteItem.

trans-unit.source: The passed in values are the PartitionKey and the RowKey, which together make up the primary key of the entity.
trans-unit.target: The passed in values are the PartitionKey and the RowKey, which together make up the primary key of the entity.

trans-unit.source: Create a file called deleteitem.php and insert the following code:
trans-unit.target: Create a file called deleteitem.php and insert the following code:

trans-unit.source: To make your application store data into the cloud you need to first create a storage account in Azure and then pass the proper authentication information to the Configuration class.
trans-unit.target: To make your application store data into the cloud you need to first create a storage account in Azure and then pass the proper authentication information to the Configuration class.

trans-unit.source: Login to the <linkText>Azure Portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Login to the <linkText>Azure Portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click the New icon on the bottom left of the portal, then click Data + Storage > Storage.
trans-unit.target: Click the New icon on the bottom left of the portal, then click Data + Storage > Storage.

trans-unit.source: Give the storage account a unique name and create a new <linkText>resource group</linkText><title></title> for it.
trans-unit.target: Give the storage account a unique name and create a new <linkText>resource group</linkText><title></title> for it.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a new storage account</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a new storage account</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the storage account has been created, the Notifications button will flash a green SUCCESS and the storage account's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.
trans-unit.target: When the storage account has been created, the Notifications button will flash a green SUCCESS and the storage account's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.

trans-unit.source: Click the Settings part in the storage account's blade.
trans-unit.target: Click the Settings part in the storage account's blade.

trans-unit.source: Take note of the account name and the primary key.
trans-unit.target: Take note of the account name and the primary key.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Select Manage Keys</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Select Manage Keys</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Open init.php and replace [YOUR_STORAGE_ACCOUNT_NAME] and [YOUR_STORAGE_ACCOUNT_KEY] with the account name and key you took note of in the last step.
trans-unit.target: Open init.php and replace [YOUR_STORAGE_ACCOUNT_NAME] and [YOUR_STORAGE_ACCOUNT_KEY] with the account name and key you took note of in the last step.

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create an Azure web app:
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create an Azure web app:

trans-unit.source: Login to the <linkText>Azure Portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Login to the <linkText>Azure Portal[management-portal]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Create an empty web app with the instructions at <linkText>How to: Create a web app Using the Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Create an empty web app with the instructions at <linkText>How to: Create a web app Using the Azure Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to create a new <linkText>App Service plan</linkText><title></title> and select the resource group you created previously for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to create a new <linkText>App Service plan</linkText><title></title> and select the resource group you created previously for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: When the web app has been created, the Notifications button will flash a green SUCCESS and the web app's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.
trans-unit.target: When the web app has been created, the Notifications button will flash a green SUCCESS and the web app's blade is open to show that it belongs to the new resource group you created.

trans-unit.source: In the web app's blade, click Set up continuous deployment, and choose Local Git Repository.
trans-unit.target: In the web app's blade, click Set up continuous deployment, and choose Local Git Repository.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Set up Git publishing</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Set up Git publishing</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Before you can deploy your local Git repository to Azure, you must also set up deployment credentials.
trans-unit.target: Before you can deploy your local Git repository to Azure, you must also set up deployment credentials.

trans-unit.source: In the web app's blade, click All Settings > Deployment credentials to configure the credentials.
trans-unit.target: In the web app's blade, click All Settings > Deployment credentials to configure the credentials.

trans-unit.source: Click Save when you're done.
trans-unit.target: Click Save when you're done.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create publishing credentials</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create publishing credentials</linkText>

trans-unit.source: It will take a few seconds to set up your repository.
trans-unit.target: It will take a few seconds to set up your repository.

trans-unit.source: Once the Git repository is ready, you now push your changes to it.
trans-unit.target: Once the Git repository is ready, you now push your changes to it.

trans-unit.source: You can find the repo URL by clicking the same deployment part in the web app's blade.
trans-unit.target: You can find the repo URL by clicking the same deployment part in the web app's blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Git deployment instructions returned after creating a repository for the web app.</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Git deployment instructions returned after creating a repository for the web app.</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note the instructions, as these will be used in the next section to publish the application.
trans-unit.target: Note the instructions, as these will be used in the next section to publish the application.

trans-unit.source: To publish your application with Git, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To publish your application with Git, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: Open the vendor/microsoft/windowsazure folder under the root of the application and delete the following files and folders:
trans-unit.target: Open the vendor/microsoft/windowsazure folder under the root of the application and delete the following files and folders:

trans-unit.source: .git
trans-unit.target: .git

trans-unit.source: .gitattributes
trans-unit.target: .gitattributes

trans-unit.source: .gitignore
trans-unit.target: .gitignore

trans-unit.source: When the Composer package manager downloads the Azure client libraries and their dependencies it does so by cloning the GitHub repository that they reside in.
trans-unit.target: When the Composer package manager downloads the Azure client libraries and their dependencies it does so by cloning the GitHub repository that they reside in.

trans-unit.source: In the next step, the application will be deployed via Git by creating a repository out of the root folder of the application.
trans-unit.target: In the next step, the application will be deployed via Git by creating a repository out of the root folder of the application.

trans-unit.source: Git will ignore the sub-repository where the client libraries live unless the repository-specific files are removed.
trans-unit.target: Git will ignore the sub-repository where the client libraries live unless the repository-specific files are removed.

trans-unit.source: Open GitBash (or a terminal, if Git is in your PATH), change directories to the root directory of your application, and run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Open GitBash (or a terminal, if Git is in your PATH), change directories to the root directory of your application, and run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for the password you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for the password you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Browse to http://[your web app domain]/createtable.php to create the table for the application.
trans-unit.target: Browse to http://[your web app domain]/createtable.php to create the table for the application.

trans-unit.source: Browse to http://[your web app domain]/index.php to begin using the application.
trans-unit.target: Browse to http://[your web app domain]/index.php to begin using the application.

trans-unit.source: After you have published your application, you can begin making changes to it and use Git to publish them.
trans-unit.target: After you have published your application, you can begin making changes to it and use Git to publish them.

trans-unit.source: To publish changes to application, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To publish changes to application, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Make changes to your application locally.
trans-unit.target: Make changes to your application locally.

trans-unit.source: Open GitBash (or a terminal, it Git is in your PATH), change directories to the root directory of your application, and run the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Open GitBash (or a terminal, it Git is in your PATH), change directories to the root directory of your application, and run the following commands:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted for the password you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted for the password you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Browse to http://[your web app domain]/index.php to see your changes.
trans-unit.target: Browse to http://[your web app domain]/index.php to see your changes.

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <linkText>Reference for navigating the portal</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <linkText>Reference for navigating the portal</linkText><title></title>
